msDesc.head: Petrarch, Rime; Trionfi, in Latin and Italian; Ferrara, Italy, s. xv2

msContents.summary: The manuscript is fully described by N. Mann, 'Petrarch manuscripts in the British Isles' Italia medioevale e umanistica, 18 (1975), 139–527, at 505–07.

msItem.author: Petrarch
msItem.title: Rime
msItem.rubric: Francisci Petrarchæ Poetæ. Clarissimi: Carmen: Rithimonos. Elegicvm in Lavram. Feliciter. Incipit.
msItem.incipit: Voi Chascoltate in Rime. Sparse il svono. Di quei sospiri on die nutriua il core
msItem.explicit: di castita per che ladorni et pregi.
msItem.note: Rime nos. 1, 3, 2, 4–112, ‘Quella ghirlanda’ (Rime, trionfi e poesie latini, ed. F. Neri et al. (Milan, 1954), Rime disperse, no. 19); Rime, nos. 113–20, 122, ‘Donna mi vien …’ (ed. Neri et al., Rime disperse, no. 13); Rime, nos. 123–9, 121, 130–263; ed. Neri et al., 3–337.

msItem.author: Petrarch
msItem.title: Rime
msItem.rubric: Que sequuntur post mortem domine Lauree scripta sunt. Ita enim proprio codice domini Francisci annotatum est. Et charte quatuor pretermisse vacuæ. Canzone xxviiij.
msItem.incipit: Io uo pensando et nel pensier massale
msItem.explicit: chaccolga il mio spirto ultimo in pace.

msItem.author: Petrarch
msItem.title: Nota di Laura
msItem.rubric: Scriptum manu propria domini .F. P. in quodam eius Virgilio uisum est.
msItem.incipit: Laura propriis uirtutibus illustris et meis longum celebrata carminibus
msItem.note: pr. P. de Nolhac, Pétrarque et l’humanisme (Paris, 1907), ii. 286–7. Fols. 141v–2v are blank.

msItem.author: Petrarch
msItem.title: Trionfi
msItem.rubric: Amor .D. Francisci Petrarcæ poeæ laureati Triumphi sex incipit et primo

msItem.incipit: NEL TEMPO CHE RINOVA I MEI SOSPIRI
msItem.explicit: vien catenato Ioue inanti al carro.
msItem.note: Triumphus Cupidinis, I, ed. Neri et al., 481–7.

msItem.incipit: Era si pieno il cor di merauiglie
msItem.explicit: et qual el mel temprato cum lasentio
msItem.note: Triumphus Cupidinis, III, ed. Neri et al., 494–501.

msItem.incipit: Poscia che mia fortuna in forzaltrui
msItem.explicit: Chel pie ua nanzi et locchio torna a dietro
msItem.note: Triumphus Cupidinis, IV, ed. Neri et al., 501–8.

msItem.incipit: Stanco gia di mirar non satio anchora
msItem.explicit: et dun pomo beffata al fin Cidippe
msItem.note: Triumphus Cupidinis, II, ed. Neri et al., 487–94.

msItem.rubric: Lavra. Capitulum quintum. Triumphus secundus qualiter domina Laura triumphauit de Cupidine.
msItem.incipit: QVANDO AD VN GIOGO ED AD VN TEMPO
msItem.explicit: fra gli altri uidi Hippolyto et Ioseppe
msItem.note: Triumphus Pudicitiæ, ed. Neri et al., 509–16.

msItem.rubric: Mors. Capitulum sextum. Triumphus tertius qualiter mors triumphauit de domina Lavra.
msItem.explicit: Morte bella parea nel suo bel uiso
msItem.note: Triumphus Mortis, ed. Neri et al., 517–23.

msItem.incipit: Quanti gia nella eta matura et agra
msItem.explicit: quella per cui ben far prima mi piacque
msItem.note: Triumphus Mortis, fragment, ed. Neri et al., 563–4.

msItem.incipit: La nocte che segui lhorribil caso
msItem.explicit: Tu starai in terra senza me gran tempo
msItem.note: Triumphus Mortis, II, ed. Neri et al., 523–30.

msItem.explicit: poi alla fine uidi Artuso et Karlo
msItem.note: Triumphus Fame, early redaction, ed. Neri et al., 564–70.

msItem.rubric: FAMA. Capitulum decimum. Quartus triumphus qualiter Fama triumphauit de MORTE.
msItem.incipit: DA POI CHE MORTE TRIVMPHO DEL VOLTO
msItem.explicit: Come aduien a cui virtu inimichi relinque
msItem.note: Triumphus Fame, I, ed. Neri et al., 531–6.
Triumphus Fame, II, ed. Neri et al., 536–43.

msItem.incipit: Io non sapea di tal uista leuarme
msItem.explicit: Qui basta lascio et piu di lor non seruo auante
msItem.note: Triumphus Fame, III, ed. Neri et al., 543–7 with one additional verse.

msItem.rubric: TEMPVS. Capitulum tertiumdecimum. Triumphus quintus qualiter tempus triumphat.
msItem.incipit: NEL AVREO ALBERGO CVM LAVRORA INANZI
msItem.explicit: Cosi il tempo triumpha e nomi el mondo
msItem.note: Triumphus Temporis, ed. Neri et al., 548–53.

msItem.rubric: Eternitas. Capitulum quartumdecimum. Triumphus sextus et ultimus de œternitate.
msItem.incipit: DA POI CHE SOTTO LCIEL COSA NON VIDI
msItem.explicit: Or che fia aduncha ariuiderla in cielo.
msItem.finalRubric: Finis. Sit laus Christo omnipotenti deo.
msItem.note: Triumphus Eternitatis, ed. Neri et al., 554–9.

supportDesc.extent:
180 leaves preceded and followed by one post-medieval paper flyleaf 223 140
160 60–75
supportDesc.collation: 1–1310 1412 15–1710 188. Plain vertical catchwords. No quire letters or numbers.

layoutDesc.layout: One column, 29 lines to a full page. Ruled in crayon.

handDesc.handNote: Humanistic cursive (presumably by a Ferrarese scribe: see History, below) with gold rustic capitals at beginning of text, fol. 1r, and rustic capitals in alternate black and sanguine at beginning of text, fol. 143r. Punctuated by virgula and medial point, singly and together.

decoDesc.decoNote: Confined within a rectangular E-shaped frame on fol. 1r is an illuminated border with white vine tendrils on a green, blue, and crimson background spattered with gold spots. On fol. 143r is an initial in a similar style but not illuminated.
Throughout there are plain two-line blue and red capitals for verses. Headings are in sanguine. Not recorded by Alexander and Temple.

binding.p: Sewn on three bands, between millboards covered with plain parchment, 18th century; probably Italian. On the spine is ‘Petrarca M.S.’ and a label bearing a number (see History below).

history.provenance: Probably of Ferrarese origin: see Mann (above, headnote), 507 n. 1, for features shared with other manuscripts that can be connected with Ferrara.
A coat of arms has been erased from the foot of the border on fol. 1r.
On a label on the spine is an unidentified library number ‘300’ (s. xviii) and, less certain, ‘176’.

After 1853 the book was given to Exeter by the Fellow Librarian, C. W. Boase, who acquired it from Thomas Thorpe. The mark l/lg/—or 1/1g/—on the front pastedown is presumably Thorpe’s and ‘[£]4/4/0’ there is also probably his, but ‘P’ is less certainly his and ‘1108’ is probably not.
Exeter library identifications are, on the front pastedown, the Eric Gill bookplate of 1931 and on it ‘CLXXXVII’ and ‘169 I’.

source.bibl: Andrew G. Watson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Exeter College, Oxford (Oxford: Oxford University Press), 2000.
